On Saturday, November 3rd, 2018, we will be conducting our annual food packaging drive at the Salvation Army. With the support of other community organizations and volunteers we will package over 20,000 meals for local harlem food pantries. We are looking for an experienced photographer who can take amazing pictures at our event. If interested please apply here. Hope to see you there!
10037.title: Photographer Needed for our Food Packaging Event

10036.description: Sunday November 18th: the no-deity Church of Good Deeds will be collecting gently used shoes, clothing, linens, and housewares from New Yorkers in the morning, and distributing everything for free to all who come by in the afternoon. Anita's Way (the huge covered passageway connecting 42nd and 43rd Streets between 6th and Broadway) has been donated by NYC and ChaShaMa as the venue for this event. All are welcome to volunteer or to take items - or both!! Volunteers will sort clothing, interact with donors and people who come to take things, and/or carry some items (if possible) to and from trucks. The Church of Good Deeds (www.ChurchOfGoodDeeds.org) is a philosophical religion with no deity or dogma: we believe in faith in people and practice faith in action. Our mission is to bring people together in community, encouraging and enabling Altruism as a necessary part of daily life. Thank you!!! Leon Feingold, Director The Church of Good Deeds 917.325.4548 917.677.5433 fax www.facebook.com/ChurchOfGoodDeeds www.ChurchOfGoodDeeds.org No good deed goes unnoticed.
10036.title: Good Deeds clothing, shoes, and housewares giveaway - volunteers and donations needed!

10036.description: Welcome to our Annual Day of Giving Thanksgiving Day Volunteers needed Nov 21, 2108 , Help set-up for the next day (Thanksgiving )- 4:30 pm to 6:30 pm All ages welcome Nov 22, 2018, all volunteers must report by 10:00 am Meal Distribution Location: Project FIND-Coffeehouse 331 West 42nd Street between 8th and 9Th Avenue Project FIND will service the Home-bound and Homeless on Thanksgiving Day With your help, we will provide seniors and homeless with a full traditional Hot Thanksgiving Day meal in their homes and on the streets. You must be registered with us in order to be admitted. descort@projectfind.org Volunteers with or without cars are welcome, all ages. Enrollment from October 8 th 2018 to Nov 12, 2108 Please visit our web-site www.projectfind.org Time of event: 9:30 am to 12noon For more information please contact descort@projectfind.org Donations are welcome
10036.title: Thanksgiving Day Celebration of Giving

10036.description: Volunteer teachers are needed for our TASC (formerly \"GED\") classes. These classes meet on Tuesdays and Thursdays (other time slots will become available later in the fall as the program is expanded). We teach all five subjects that comprise the exam, with the majority of classroom time devoted to the two main subjects: Reading comprehension (Tuesdays) and Math (Thursdays). Each TASC class meets from 6-7:30pm to cover the main subjects, with an additional half-hour (7:30-8pm) allotted for instruction in the other subject areas, as well as tutoring individual students. While some of our volunteers work with us more than one day a week, we ask for a minimum time commitment of a single evening session. Prior teaching experience is a plus. For those who have a passion for teaching but lack formal experience, we provide training as well as a mentoring program, which pairs less experienced volunteers with more experienced ones. Note: The location where we teach our TASC classes is at 459 W 46th Street, but a new volunteer's first visit and subsequent orientation will take place at our main building (located nearby at 422 West 57th St). Together One New York is a non-profit organization whose volunteers are passionate about providing vital resources to immigrants, as well adult education programs for all members of the NYC community. In addition to our TASC classes, resources include language classes, a citizenship program, and English conversation classes. With your help, we can expand our outreach and increase the number of people served. Thank you for considering us! For more information, please visit: http://togetheronenewyork.org/
10036.title: Volunteer Teacher for Adult High School Equivalency Program

10036.description: ABOUT THE MENTORSHIP As a High School or College Access Mentor you will guide the success of BTNY High School students by supporting them through a year of high school, helping them to prepare for success in a 4-year college. YOUR RESPONSIBILITIES WILL INCLUDE... Mentor a core group of 12-15 1high school students in a specific grade level. Ensure that your students meet organizational expectations, including: 85% or above in each academic class Participation in at least two extracurricular activities Attendance to all six Super Saturdays (and Seminars if in 9 th or 10 th grades) College Access Mentors only: Apply to at least 12 best fit colleges (including at least 1 SUNY and 1 CUNY school) College Access Mentors only: Submit all financial aid applications College Access Mentors only: Apply to at least 5 scholarships Conduct monthly check-ins by phone or video chat with a core group of 12-15 students, and report the information gathered during those meetings in a timely fashion Work onsite during six Saturdays throughout the academic year with other HSMs, High School Coordinators and High School Director Plan and co-teach grade level college readiness workshops for a small class of high school students with another Mentor Complete 24+ hours of training and at least four hours of professional development during the year Receiving feedback constructively in order to improve performance Tracking and reporting student data Other duties based on the grade level you are assigned WE’RE LOOKING FOR SOMEONE WHO... Can demonstrate experience and results with similar responsibilities to those listed above Is passionate about forming mentoring relationships with students Is passionate about supporting low-income, high-achieving students to earn admission to selective 4-year colleges Is a current college student, graduate student, or recent college graduate based in the New York City area during the academic year Maintains / maintained at least a 3.0 GPA Will respond to email, phone calls, and texts from students and staff within 24 hours Can commit to the entire 2018-19 academic year Is confident with MS Office (Word, Excel, and PowerPoint in particular), Google Suite, and comfortable learning new systems. Experience with Salesforce or other databases a plus. HIGH SCHOOL/COLLEGE ACCESS MENTOR TENTATIVE CALENDAR... Late August/ Early September - three full days of High School Mentor Training. Mentors can choose either August 17-19 or August 24-26. High School Curriculum Night: August 29. Tentative Professional Development Dates (Mentors should choose at least two to attend) September 12/13 October 16/17 February 20/21 April 23/24 Tentative Super Saturday Dates: September 22 November 10 December 15 February 9 March 23 May 11 Between Super Saturdays: Remotely check in with each of your 12-15 students Plan your lesson for the upcoming Super Saturday Check-in Meeting with assigned High School Coordinator Attend Professional Development Meeting with all HSMs and High School Coordinators June - Complete Mentorship ANTICIPATED TIME COMMITMENT... This mentorship requires approximately 145-160 hours throughout the academic year, including: 24 hours of internship training - August/ September 50 hours of Saturday Programming -6 Saturdays throughout the academic year, 7am-4pm 100 hours of student check-ins - 30 minute check-ins with each student within your cohort of 12-13 following each of the 6 Saturday programs, plus a half hour to report data gathered from each series of check-in’s 12 hours of pre-Saturday lesson planning - About 2 hours of lesson planning per Saturday program 10 hours of professional development support - 1 hour meeting with assigned High School Coordinator between each Saturday program, plus two two-hour sessions chosen by the HSM 2 hours to attend the Fall Curriculum Night 2 hours to attend one night of Seminar (only 9th and 10th grade mentors) COMPENSATION BTNY is strongly believes in selecting the top, qualified candidates. As a part of your offer you can expect to receive the following: A base stipend of $1,750 (High School Mentors - 9th to 11th grade) or $2,250 (College Access Mentors - 12th grade) Candidates can also choose to volunteer their time A pre-paid MetroCard card to cover internship related travel expenses Ongoing professional development support, including PD focused meetings and letters of recommendation TO APPLY Complete the High School Mentor application online (https://tinyurl.com/BTNYMentor2018) by Sunday, July 22 nd at 11:59PM and indicate your interest in CAM where prompted. This application also includes: Resume Current or Most Recent College Transcript (if available) Recommendation Form ( link shared through application, can be completed through August 5 th) If you have any questions, please e-mail seasonal@btny.org
10036.title: Mentor NYC Students!

10031.description: City Tutors is looking for a professional(s) to serve as a mentor for a City College of New York (CUNY) course called Vocation, Career and Self-Development which runs from 5-7PM on Thursdays in the Fall semeter. The mentor would help students in the class with revising their resumes, and would conduct mock interviews. Ideally the mentor would be available to come in the class from 6-7pm at least during the first few sessions so that a relationship with the students can quickly be established. Most of the work can be done over virtual platform. The mentor would work closely in coordination with the instructor of the course. Here is a description of the course: This course aims to provide students with practical tools and applied knowledge on how best to find a fulfilling job in today’s, increasingly competitive, job market. It is divided in four parts, or modules. The first deals with vocation; that is, establishing what career path(s) best fit your talents, values and aspirations. The second aims at establishing what kind of experience you need to best achieve your career goals, both in terms of academic study and extra-curricular activities. The third concerns the networking and information-gathering skills you will need, both online and in person, to find the right job opportunities for you. Finally, the last and largest module deals with self-presentation and interviewing techniques, with specific training and evaluation sessions on résumé and cover-letter writing as well as job interview strategy and performance. As an applied and participatory course, classes will involve a variety of pedagogical exercises in addition to lectures by the instructor and a number of invited guests from the business world. Students will be required to participate in mock interviews, acting both as 'interviewers’ and 'interviewees’, but also to comment on and evaluate on each other’s résumés and cover letters, and participate in a number of other in-class exercises aimed at fostering self-awareness, networking skills and team-building ability.
10031.title: Seeking Mentor(s) to support a CCNY course titled: Vocation, Career, and Self-Development

10030.description: Behind the Book (www.behindthebook.org) is a non-profit literacy organization that inspires New York City public school students to love reading. Through our rich, innovative programs, accomplished authors visit high-needs pre-K-12 classrooms, where they guide students in creating their own writing projects based on the theme of the author's book. BtB seeks volunteer photographers and videographers to document students, authors, and volunteer coaches during classroom workshops and field trips. It's ideal if you have experience working with pre-K to high school-age students. You may also cover fundraising and other events. Examples of photos can be found on our Instagram feed at www.instagram.com/behindthebook/. To apply, or for more information, contact volunteer@behindthebook.org. Please include a link to your website, portfolio or other samples of your work in either or both areas.
10030.title: Photographer/Videographer

10033.description: Food pantry volunteers are needed in Washington Heights. The pantry is open Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday. This client choice food pantry serves New Yorkers in need. 10033.title: Washington Heights Food Pantry Volunteer

07430.description: ENROLLMENT FOR VOLUNTEERS FOR PONY POWER THERAPIES FALL SEMESTER IS NOW OPEN! Pony Power Therapies is looking for volunteers to assist in therapeutic horse-back riding lessons as lead walkers for our Fall Semester! Lead walkers are responsible for handling the horse during lessons and only those with previous horse experience will be assigned as Lead Walkers. Lessons run Sunday through Thursday. Our Fall Semester begins on Tuesday, September 11th and runs through to Thursday, December 20th. Volunteer Handbook, application and schedule will be emailed to you and application needs to be returned to our office prior to registering for a volunteer training class. Pony Power Therapies gives special needs and at-risk children and adults a unique opportunity to ride, care for and interact with horses. Our riding and non-riding activities enhance individuals' physical, social and emotional well-being in a safe, nurturing farm environment. Please visit www.ponypowernj.org for more information on Pony Power Therapies. Interested individuals can email volunteers@ponypowernj.org or call our office at 201-934-1001.

Under the supervision of a certified riding instructor, the side walker walks next to the horse to provide support to the rider as needed. Lessons run Sunday through Thursday. Our Fall Semester begins on Tuesday, September 11th and runs through to Thursday, December 20th. 10038.description: StreetWise Partners is a non-profit that aims to reduce unemployment within the low-income communities of Washington, D.C. and NYC through our unique mentoring model program. We also host skills-based, one-time volunteer opportunities to help prepare our mentees with the skills, resources, and access to networks they need to secure employment! Are you interested in helping our mentees develop their professional skills? If so, sign-up for the StreetWise Partners Speed Networking and Mock Interview events! Speed Networking (2.5 hours): Give mentees the opportunity to expand their professional network, develop their confidence in public speaking, and perfect their '60-second pitch’. Schedule: Tuesday, October 30th PwC (300 Madison Ave.) or Marsh & McLennan Companies (1166 Avenue of the Americas) Wednesday, October 31st Deutsche Bank (60 Wall Street) Thursday, November 1st Morgan Stanley (1585 Broadway) Time: 6:30 - 9:00pm Choose the event, day and location that works for you! Mock Interview Day (2.5 hours): Conduct 3 mock interviews in the roles of \"HR Manager,\" \"Line Manager\" or \"CEO\" and provide feedback to our motivated, job-seeking mentees so they leave prepared to ace their next job interview! Schedule: Tuesday, November 27th PwC (300 Madison Ave.) or Marsh & McLennan Companies (1166 Avenue of the Americas) Wednesday, November 28th Deutsche Bank (60 Wall Street) Thursday, November 29th Morgan Stanley (1585 Broadway) Time: 6:30 - 9:00pm If you are interested in signing up or learning more please contact April Griswold, Volunteer Relations Manager @ april@streetwisepartners.org. You can also sign-up on our website at www.streetwisepartners.org. We hope to see you there!
10038.title: Join us for Speed Networking and Mock Interview Events-Sign Up Today!

10038.description: Looking for career oriented volunteers who want to help our non-native English speakers to improve their job interview skills. You would practice one on one with adults from 15 different countries and help them to be more successful in seeking jobs in their new country of residence.
10038.title: Help adults sharpen their interview skills

10038.description: Hamilton-Madison House is looking for volunteers on Saturdays from 11:00am till 3:30pm to help tutor and teach kids, ages 6-17, Math and Literacy. Program starts October 2018 and will run until June 2019.Volunteers must make at least a one month commitment.
10038.title: Are you good in math and reading?Become a tutor for a group of lively and humorous 6-17 year-olds

10038.description: American Youth Table Tennis seeks interested college students in the New York City Metro Area to teach high school students the sport of table tennis, leadership, fair play, respect and teamwork. Table Tennis expertise required. As a volunteer coach you will receive a small per visit stipend per visit to cover transportation costs and effort. We will assign you to a New York City High School Table Tennis Program as an Assistant Table Tennis Coach. Duties will include, teaching basic and intermediate table tennis - footwork, serve, serve return, backhand, forehand, tactics, loop, loop drive as well as serving multi-ball and providing a positive and exciting framework for play, and dialog. American Youth Table Tennis and New York City Department of Education have teamed up to make this opportunity available to you. Table Tennis is an official varsity sport in New York City. We will be accepting applications in November and through to the end of January. We are in need of expert collegiate table tennis players to assist in selected High School Programs for the 2017-18 season which begins in December and Continues through March 2018 As an Assistant Coach, you will be giving back to the New York City community by imparting your table tennis knowledge on receptive and interested high school students. This program will look good on your resume and will help the next generation of collegiate table tennis players.
10038.title: Youth Table Tennis Coach - Collegiate Internship Program

10543.description: Open Door Family Medical Centers, in partnership with Feeding Westchester (formerly the Food Bank of Westchester) and the Larchmont Mamaroneck Hunger Task Force, hosts a massive giveaway of over 10,000 pounds fresh produce donated by Hunts on the last Saturday of each month! 10543.title: Spread the Wealth! Fresh Nutritious Produce Free Market

07960.description: We are looking for a communications intern to start ASAP, with a passion for writing and social change to help us grow our organization and cause. Through strategic press and influencer outreach, beautifully written op-eds, engagement with our social media audiences, and work with our website you will help ensure that a broad audience feels the passion that is at the core of our organization. You’ll work closely with our advocacy coordinator and organizers to grow the movement and make sure that our resources get into the hands of those who need them the most. Responsibilities participate in bi-weekly meetings with the team to discuss organization optimization ideas * Manage our social media platforms (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter) * PR Support include press outreach-press releases and press advisories * Create quality content for our website and marketing materials * Help manage our online advertising, including Google, Facebook, and Retargeted ads * Work with visual team to assist with video and design production as needed Required Skills/Experience * Excellent writing ability * Eagerness to learn * Press outreach and media relations * Unshakable positivity * Self-starter and problem solver * Design and/or video production skills preferred Requirements * Bilingual (English and Spanish) * Proficiency in Microsoft Office (Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Outlook, Internet Explorer) required * Experience with Adobe web elements (e.g. Photoshop, InDesign, Illustrator) preferred * Strong oral and written communications skills. This includes the ability to speak clearly and persuasively in positive or negative situations, listen and get clarification, as well as the ability to write clearly and informatively * Poise and the ability to present him or herself to others with professionalism and maturity * An energetic and self-motivated attitude * Attention to detail, multi-tasking skills and the ability to thrive in a deadline driven environment * Willingness to express and share thoughts and ideas to contribute to team brainstorm sessions * Ability to work with a flexible schedule in order to be available for scheduled events, including nights, weekends and holidays * Willingness and eagerness to learn, easily coachable
07960.title: Communications Volunteer
07960.org: WIND OF THE SPIRIT IMMIGRANT RESOURCE CENTER INC

07960.description: We are beginning to recruit interested volunteers for our upcoming New Jersey Confidential Sexual Violence Victim Advocate (CSVA) training, which is slated to begin in October 2018 one day a week from 5:30 PM-9:30PM for 10 weeks. During the 40 hour training volunteers are educated about topics regarding sexual assault statistics, prevention, and response. Crisis intervention and advocacy support skills are taught and guest speakers, including law enforcement, military experts, and mental health professionals present information. When the volunteer completes the training and receives the CSVA status, they are required to manage the crisis hotline for three 12 hour shifts per month. (The hotline is forwarded to the volunteer's telephone for their shifts.) In addition to hotline, the advocate's second responsibility per shift is to accompany survivors of sexual assault to the hospital as needed. Although this is a challenging volunteer position, the experience is very rewarding (and looks great on a resume too)! Join our team and support survivors!
07960.title: Sexual Assault Response Team Advocate Training

10303.description: We are currently seeking two self-motivated individuals with good interpersonal, communication and customer service skills to volunteer with our organization. Responsibilities for the position will include, overseeing all aspects of general office coordination, maintaining office calendar to coordinate work flow and meetings, interacting with clients, vendors and visitors, answering telephones and transfer calls to appropriate staff member, performing general clerical duties to include, but not limited to, bookkeeping, copying, faxing, mailing and filing, coordinating and directing office services, such as records, budget preparation, personnel and housekeeping. The selected individuals will also collect and maintain inventory of office equipment and supplies, make travel arrangements for staff, board and volunteers and performing other duties as requested. Work hours are very flexible. If interested, please forward resume to wewal75@yahoo.com.

We could also schedule your shift according to your availability. Students and retirees are encouraged to apply. Please email your resume and cover letter to wewal75@yahoo.com .
10303.title: OFFICE ASSISTANT/OFFICE MANAGER
10303.org: World Association for Community Empowerment, Inc.

10303.description: We are currently looking for volunteers with teaching experience or college students/graduates to help disadvantage children in the Parkhill/Stapleton and Arlington Terrace community on Staten Island with home work help and after school tutorial. The afterschool program opportunity is available from 3:00 PM to 6:00 PM Mondays to Fridays. Volunteers may choose to work one day a week or up to five days a week based on availability. 10303.org: World Association for Community Empowerment, Inc.

10301.description: We are an agency that serves homebound older adults. Our mission is to keep them in their homes for as long as possible. Many of them are socially isolated and the only person they see each day is the driver who comes to drop off their meals on wheels. This does not provide the socialization they so desperately need. This is why we need you to be a friend to an older adult. To have a cup of coffee, tea, play cards, take a walk and/or just chat. We only ask for an hour per week. Volunteers can be from 18 to 80. To find out more about this opportunity please contact Rosanne McAllister 718-981-6226 ext. 141.
10301.title: Volunteers needed in Staten Island to Brighten the Lives of Older Adults.
10301.org: COMMUNITY AGENCY FOR SENIOR CITIZENS INC

10301.description: We have a lovely wheelchair bound senior who spends most of her days alone. This Client does not have much of a family. She loves old movies, and also loves to knit and crochet (she can even teach you!). She has 2 very friendly dogs but would love someone to come and chat with her and even sharpen her computer skills. If you can get to Travis and can spare one hour per week, please contact Rosanne McAllister at 718 981-6226, ext 141 for further information. Thanks in advance for your kindness. Your kindness will benefit someone who is alone and isolated.
10301.title: STATEN ISLANDERS!  Can you travel to Travis?
10301.org: COMMUNITY AGENCY FOR SENIOR CITIZENS INC

10301.description: We are Community Agency for Senior Citizens, Inc. We have been in Staten Island for over 40 years. We only serve Older Adults. The program is called the Friendly Visiting Program. The program began in January/2017. We look to \"Match\" you with an Older Adult. The program asks that you spend one hour in the Client's home. While visiting the Client, you can have a cup of coffee/tea, play a table top game, cards, read a book together, watch a movie. The visit is what you both decide upon. This is a building block relationship. So far, many of our \"Match's\" have become good friends and look forward to these weekly visits. Your volunteering brings much happiness to someone who is alone and isolated.
10301.title: Do You Want to Brighten Someone's Day? Volunteer's Are the Sunshine that Homebound Adult's Need
10301.org: COMMUNITY AGENCY FOR SENIOR CITIZENS INC

07702.description: Pinwheel place is looking high and low for passionate people who want to help children in crisis! We are hosting a Dr. Seuss themed basket auction and are looking for our CATS IN THE HATS to make our event come alive ! This opportunity is for the day of the event and we are looking for dedicated people to help with setting up, working the event and/or cleaning up!
07702.title: LOOKING FOR CATS IN THE HATS  for our tricky tray

10028.description: Join us at the 16 National MoneyPOWER Conference. Educators will have the opportunity to visit workshops, complimentary consultations, a resources fair, and take our Financial Literacy Certification Test. As a volunteer, you will assist with directing guests, setting up workshop rooms, and clean up from breakfast, as well as clean up at the end of the conference.

10028.description: Enthusiastic volunteers are needed to introduce school children to art and museums. We will train you to give guided tours at the Brooklyn Museum of Art and Metropolitan Museum of Art, and to go into the classroom to prepare the students for their visit. Tours take place Monday through Friday, during the school year, between the hours of 10am and 1pm. ArtWorks volunteers are in 20 schools throughout the five boroughs and our classroom teachers love us!
10028.title: "Introduce Children to Art and Museums"

10028.description: We are in need of a CPR Instructor to teach some of the mothers of Nurse-Family Partnership. NFP sends specially trained nurses to do home visits with low-income first time mothers from the time they are pregnant until their babies are 2 years of age. We at Friends of NYC Nurse-Family Partnershipi arrange various learning opportunities for the mothers at sites in the 5 boroughs. As funds are extremely limited, we need a volunteer to do a one-hour non-certified class in CPR. The moms do not need to be certified. They want to learn CPR for babies and toddlers as well as the fundamentals for preventing choking. If you have some time to spare on a weekday for a very worthy cause, please contact us and let us know your credentials.
10028.title: CPR INSTRUCTOR FOR NON-CERTIFIED CLASS
10028.org: FRIENDS OF NEW YORK CITY NURSE FAMILY PARTNERSHIP INC

10028.description: Do you have a few hours to spend helping us devlop programs for young mothers and their babies? The mission of Friends of NYC Nurse-Family Partnereship is to improve the lives of babies and their mothers by providing enhanced benefits for the nationally renowned Nurse-Family Partnership. NFP sends registered nurses to make regular visits to first-time, low-income mothers, from the time the mothers are pregnant until their babies are 2. Friends of NYC NFP is developing and leading LEAP (Learn, Eat, and Play) programs which help the mothers meet and socialize with other young moms while learning about nutrition, finance, making toys out of household objects and much more. We need VOLUNTEERS who can help us create interesting play times for the babies. We'd like to: Showing mothers the importance of interactions with their baby Teach about a rich learning environment Show exercises which will allow babies to explore and learn Programs are held around midday during the week at locations in the boroughs of NYC. If interested, please send resume and phone number.
10028.title: Pre-School Teacher
10028.org: FRIENDS OF NEW YORK CITY NURSE FAMILY PARTNERSHIP INC

10028.description: Are you a singer, guitar player, or have other musical talents appropriate for young mothers and their babies? The babies are all under 2 years of age. If you have appropriate musical experience and talent and would like to entertain in such a situation and you are available week days, we would like to hear from you. Events typically last 2-3 hours; frequency would be once a quarter or more. Please send a note describing your musical background;experience with very young children a big plus. SEND YOUR RESUME AND PHONE NUMBER.
10028.title: Guitarist or Keyboard Player for Mother/Baby Events
10028.org: FRIENDS OF NEW YORK CITY NURSE FAMILY PARTNERSHIP INC

10029.description: We're looking for several people to volunteer with our Meals on Wheels program on Saturday, November 3rd! We welcome both individual volunteers and small groups. For over 40 years, Union Settlement has provided Meals on Wheels to East Harlem's older residents that are often economically struggling and living alone. Our Meals on Wheels program currently serves approximately 450 homebound seniors each day. Prior to the volunteer date, volunteers will be sent a short training video and brief quiz to help prepare them for participation with Meals on Wheels. Volunteers will help pack hot and cold meals and then join staff on deliveries where they will get to hand out meals to our clients and interact with the East Harlem community. Volunteers are not required to have a driver's license or own a car. When: Saturday, November 3rd from 8:30am to 12:30pm Where: Jefferson Senior Center in East Harlem Interested individuals or groups should email Jeanette Iturbides -Volunteer Coordinator at jiturbides@unionsettlement.org with the subject line \"Saturday, October 13th Meals on Wheels Volunteer\".
10029.title: Volunteer with Meals on Wheels on Saturday, November 3rd!

10029.description: VOLUNTEERS ARE PRICELESS, ESPECIALLY ON THANKSGIVING DAY! With generous corporate and community support the Latino Center on Aging (LCA) has provided hot, delicious Thanksgiving meals to over twenty five thousand seniors in New York City, Newark, Paterson, Orlando and Washington, DC, since 1992. We are looking for volunteers to help us feed seniors without family this Thanksgiving Day. For details on the locations for this year, please visit: http://www.gerolatino.org/english/5822.html For East Harlem Senior Centers call: Jeanette Iturbides, (212) 828- 6103.
10029.title: 2018 Thanksgiving Day Meal for Seniors

10029.description: Do you want to get experience working with kids? Do you want to be part of our Spanish Children Class at El Taller? Come support our Spanish teacher . We are looking for a volunteer who is: -Welcoming and friendly. -Collaborative, reliable, punctual, flexible. -Willing to commit each Saturday 10am to 1pm. We offer: - A valuable experience working in a cultural organization. - Free Spanish classes.
10029.title: Assistant Teacher For Kids Spanish Classes

10029.description: Job Description: As a Cooking Class Assistant for after-school classes, you will be a key player in creating the culinary experiences that shape the future generation of creative cooks and thoughtful eaters. Along the way, you’ll have the opportunity to engage with the local community of families, chefs, and restaurants that have partnered with usto give kids from all backgrounds the opportunity to cook and eat healthy meals. Your Role: We need enthusiastic, food-savvy volunteers who are ready and eager to jump into the kitchen and lead cooking classes with middle school aged girls from East Harlem. A love for working with kids and experimenting with new recipes is a must. You will be responsible for leading students through a culinary lesson plan, ensuring kids stay safe in the kitchen, and maintaining a fun, friendly, and educational cooking environment. Professional Growth: This is your chance to get hands-on in a school classroom as you take your passions for food, cooking, education to the next level. In addition to engaging with local communities of families and students, you will also be working with a top chef from the Harlem community. Sample Tasks: Assist After-School Cooking Classes for middle school girls, teaching basic knife skills, chopping techniques, and kitchen safety Supervise groups of up to twenty students during cooking classes Set up and clean up spaces in schools as part of prep for cooking events Skills and Requirements: Cooking experience and comfortability in the kitchen (formal culinary experience is not required) Past experience working with kids Organized, creative, and able to adapt to situations on the fly Passion for education, cooking, nutrition, and teaching kids
10029.title: Cooking Class Assistant

10029.description: Help our program staff spread holiday cheer and serve Christmas meals to seniors at our Gaylord White Senior Center! We're looking for volunteers who are outgoing, friendly, and ready to pitch in to provide meals to those who may not have any other place to go for the holiday. Volunteers will help set up for the holiday meal service beginning at 9am, serve meals and chat with seniors, and then help wrap up by 2pm. Interested individuals or groups should email Jeanette Iturbides -Volunteer Coordinator at jiturbides@unionsettlement.org with the subject line \"Christmas Meal Service Volunteer\". Volunteers must be able to stay from 9am to 2pm.
10029.title: Be a Christmas Volunteer at a Senior Center!

10029.description: DREAM, an award winning youth development program, is seeking volunteer tutors to provide academic support to our middle school after-school students in East Harlem and the South Bronx. Tutors work with youth individually and in small groups to help improve student success in class, increase subject-specific retention, and contribute to overall academic enrichment and development. What You’ll Do Support academic enrichment activities, including homework help and tutoring; Provide individualized and team-wide support all after-school program activities and initiatives; Serve as a role model and build positive relationships with youth; What We’re Looking For Strong command of one or more of the following academic subjects: English, Math, Science, and/or Social Studies Previous experience working with youth; Possess creativity, enthusiasm, initative, flexibility, and patience; Solid oral communication skills; Ability to make a consistent, weekly commitment; Bachelor’s Degree (a plus); 1-2 years previous tutoring experience (a major plus). Benefits Gain invaluable experience and opportunities for professional development at an award-winning youth development program; Receive an optional professional reference upon completion of your service term; Join an incredible community of passionate staff and volunteers. Minimum Commitment: 1-2 hours per week for a full cycle. Cycle 1: October - December/ Cycle 2: February - May. When: ******Monday - Thursday******* 4pm-5pm (time depends on tutor availability and program site assignment) DREAM provides equal opportunity for all volunteers.
10029.title: Volunteer as a Middle School Tutor

10029.description: Opus 118 Harlem School of Music ( www.Opus118.org) provides high-quality music instruction in an environment that nurtures excellence and creativity. Students in the East Harlem community are served with tuition-free twice-weekly group violin instruction during regular school hours and subsidized private instruction for violin, viola, cello, guitar, and piano after school hours. Opus 118 Harlem School of Music was founded by the now-legendary Roberta Guaspari, whose fight for in-school music programs in East Harlem became the subject of a documentary ( Small Wonders) and a feature film (Music from the Heart). Roberta continues to work in East Harlem Schools while actively training the next generation of teachers for Opus 118. Opus 118’s partnership with Kaufman Music Center ( www.kaufmanmusiccenter.org) has led to an exciting growth period, and we are currently interviewing qualified individuals to intern with us for the 2018-2019 school year, helping with administrative duties and assisting both teachers and students. This is an opportunity for those interested in arts administration to get hands-on experience in multiple facets of a non-profit organization. Department: Arts Administration Reports to: Director of Programs and Development Schedule: 12 hours per week, 3-6pm M-Th. Preference given to candidates who can commit to full 30 week calendar. Duties Required: serve as contact for parents of enrolled students at one After-School Program site receive and process student registrations enroll students in classes/lessons observe lesson schedule and notify parents/faculty of confirmed times and cancellations maintain accurate records of student attendance process tuition payments manage classroom scheduling and set-up assist with program-related publications, web-content, and social media prepare program enrollment and activity reports as needed additional responsibilities to be determined as needed, including performance management and organizational projects Requirements for the Position A passion for music education and working with young people Self-starting, organized, methodical Ability to work under pressure, multi-task, have outstanding interpersonal and communication skills A desire to learn about arts administration and the different tasks found within a non-profit environment An enthusiasm for learning and a willingness to take on a variety of tasks
10029.title: Non-Profit Music Organization Volunteer

10029.description: This is a wonderful opportunity to support school staff and elementary school students during lunchtime and recess from 10:30-11:30 am. Students eat in cafeteria from 10:30-11:00 am then go out to the school yard to play from 11-11:30 am. We are looking persons who can supervise students at the lunch table then lead them to the yard and facilitate organized play. We think of organized play broadly so it can include any sports, team building games, dance, art or any other. We will supply any equipment needed. This opportunity is for the entire school year but we are looking to place a few volunteers so if you can not commit to the full school year please let us know how many months you can commit to.
10029.title: Facilitate Elementary School Organized Play (Lunchtime)
10029.org: Ps 108 Assemblyman Angelo Del Toro Educational Com

10029.description: We are currently seeking Friendly Visiting Volunteers to visit with homebound seniors in Manhattan's East Harlem and Upper East Side. Volunteers commit to visiting a senior once a week for six months to a year, or longer, to form a friendship and provide company to a senior who has expressed a desire to make a new friend. Thank you for your interest in this program!
10029.title: Visit with a Homebound Senior in East Harlem

10026.description: Each Wednesday, we prep & serve a simple vegetarian meal offering in Central Harlem for anyone who needs a meal. One can help cook and/or serve and/or clean up. Time commitment is flexible: 2 & 1/2 hours to prep/cook, 1 hour to set up/serve, 1 hour clean up. One can help out with any part of the meal. Any level of skill is accepted.
10026.title: Volunteer To Cook & Serve Every Wednesday

10027.description: The Best Buddies Friendship Walk is the number one walk in the country raising awareness and funds to support individuals with intellectuals and developmental disabilities (IDD). The walk plays a key role in funding Best Buddies programs dedicated to one-to-one friendships, leadership development and integrated job opportunities for individuals with IDD. Each walk provides an opportunity to see the Best Buddies mission at a local level. We need volunteers to help the day of as walk marshalls, greeters, tent organizers, and clean up.
10027.title: Best Buddies NYC Friendship Walk

10027.description: HEAF is seeking dedicated individuals to serve as academic coaches to providing tutoring and support and/or to serve as Teacher’s Assistants for our High Expectations (Middle School) students, grades 6-8. About HEAF: The Harlem Educational Activities Fund, Inc. (HEAF) is a comprehensive not-for-profit supplemental education and youth development organization that supports and assists dedicated students to develop the intellectual curiosity, academic ability, social values and personal resiliency they need to ensure success in school, career and life. HEAF identifies scholars in middle school and supports them until they are successfully admitted to four-year colleges through a variety of after-school, Saturday and summer programs. Purpose: Academic Tutors ensure that are students have the academic and study skills needed to succeed in middle, high school, and college. As a college bound program, HEAF’s goal is for 100% of our scholars to graduate from both high school and a four year college. To ensure all HEAF scholars realize this goal, HEAF mandates tutoring and Academic Success Programs for scholars who fall below HEAF’S minimum academic standards of 80% and above in all core class. Tutors provide assistance to students in the four core subject areas: Math, English/ELA, Science, and Social Studies and are matched with students based on the coach’s skills in specific subject areas and the student’s needs. Responsibilities: Assess and assist students with homework and test preparation in at least one of the core subjects: Math, English Language Arts (ELA), Science, and Social Studies - see below for more details about concepts covered in each subject area Evaluate and record student progress after each session Attend and participate in scheduled tutor orientation & training meetings Communicate academic progress to program staff Create a rich learning environment that aids in instructing students with various learning styles Complete and submit required documentation, including hours log Qualifications: Bachelor’s degree preferred - some college required. (Masters students in Education encouraged to apply) Advanced skills in Mathematics, English Language Arts, Science, and/or Social Studies Experience tutoring middle school students Strong work ethic and interpersonal skills Willingness to promote HEAF educational and youth development philosophy. Ability to work collaboratively with others Bilingual (Spanish/English) candidates are highly encouraged to apply. Time Commitment: Academic Tutors are asked to make a minimum of a one hour/week commitment for a minimum of one semester. HEAF’s High Expectations tutoring program operates on Saturdays from 2:30-3:30pm . Support: Orientation will be provided for all tutors at the beginning of the Fall term. Additionally, tutors are given access to a folder of resources that can be used during their sessions. Optional training sessions are offered for our program team throughout the Fall term. Benefits Build one-on-one relationships with students, while instilling confidence in themselves and their academic abilities Work as part of a collaborative and innovative team Receive ongoing training opportunities Ensure our students have the skills necessary to successfully accomplish their academic goals This position is an unpaid, volunteer position that reports to the Program Coordinator for High Expectations, and is also supported by the Volunteer Engagement Coordinator.
10027.title: Middle School Academic Tutor

10027.description: Market Access Program Intern Start Small Think Big (Start Small) is a not-for-profit organization located in Harlem. Our mission is to help under resourced individuals build and sustain thriving businesses in order to increase their personal financial security and stimulate economic activity in underserved communities in New York City. We believe that entrepreneurship results in increased innovation and sustained economic growth for everyone, in particular, those most traditionally marginalized. The Market Access Program Intern will work with the Marketing Program Manager to assist our entrepreneurs with marketing and sales business needs. This includes developing resource guides, learning more about sales opportunities in NYC and online, and supporting our communications team with a social media strategy. Job Responsibilities shall include, but are not limited to: Assist in managing Start Small Think Big social media platforms, including creating and posting content, identifying influencers in the space, and responding to comments and questions received from entrepreneurs. Research and develop informative resource guides focused on assisting entrepreneurs in identifying and addressing business challenges and community resources necessary to increase business success. Support the Marketing Program Manager in delivering services, via workshops, consultations, and project-based relationships, this includes managing logistics of events, coordinating entrepreneur attendance, and all necessary follow-up calls. Assist in developing the evaluation rubrics used by volunteer marketing experts to help entrepreneurs identify weaknesses in their current marketing practices. Preferred Skills/Qualifications: Current undergraduate student with strong interest in writing, social media, and communications, nonprofit program management, or other related disciplines. High level of computer proficiency including familiarity with Google Applications, social media (Facebook, Instagram and Twitter) and MS Office. Knowledge of programs: Buffer and Canva a plus. Demonstrated commitment to inclusive community/economic development, social and economic justice work, and/or anti-poverty work. Excellent verbal and written communication skills, time management, and interpersonal skills; Highly organized, creative and self-motivated; a strong problem-solver and analytical/critical thinker; and Experience working in low-income and/or immigrant communities. TO APPLY: Submit resume to: Eliza Edge, Market Access Program Manager at eliza@startsmallthinkbig.org (include subject line: \"[your name] Market Access Program Intern.\" This position is unpaid, but may be used for course credit where appropriate. Minimum of 20 hours/week at our office. Days are flexible. Start Small Think Big is an equal opportunity employer with a standing policy of nondiscrimination. This means that all qualified persons are accorded an equal opportunity for employment or promotion without regard to actual or perceived race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, disability, medical condition, marital status, sex, age, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, family responsibility, personal appearance, genetic information, matriculation, or political affiliation.
10027.title: Marketing Program Assistant (Internship)

11225.description: Volunteer with Behind the Book (www.behindthebook.org), a non-profit literacy organization that inspires New York City public school students to explore stories and empower their voices. Through our innovative programs, which are part of the class curricula, accomplished authors visit high-needs pre-K-12th grade classrooms to guide students in creating their own writing projects based on the theme of the author's book. You need no experience or training to volunteer. As a coach, you'll support and encourage students as they work on their projects. This field trip needs your help at a school in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, NYC. To sign up, reply with the program code to volunteer@behindthebook.org. We'll supply the address, directions, and other information when you're confirmed: Program 2415RG-R Date: Tuesday, November 13th Time: 9:45 - 11:30 AM Volunteer Role: Field trip chaperone About the program: In \"First Garden\" by Robbin Gourley , fifth-graders read about the White House kitchen garden planted by Michelle Obama to encourage healthful eating. As they explore growing their own food and cooking with fresh ingredients, students will think about family traditions for preparing meals. Chaperones will accompany the class to Whole Foods, where they’ll visit the market’s rooftop garden and choose ingredients for a salad. Supported by coaches, they’ll write about a healthy family meal, or develop their own recipe, to create a class cookbook.Their families will prepare the dishes, and join students at a celebration. For information on other program dates around the city, please visit http://www.behindthebook.org/current-volunteer-opportunities/ To join our team and receive announcements of new programs as they're scheduled, please submit our brief questionnaire at http://www.behindthebook.org/join-us/volunteer/
11225.title: Field trip chaperone  for Crown Heights, Brooklyn, NYC public school literacy program

11225.description: Academic Tutors ensure that are students have the academic and study skills needed to succeed in middle school and high school. As a college bound program, HEAF’s goal is for 100% of our scholars to graduate from both high school and a four year college. To ensure all HEAF scholars realize this goal, HEAF mandates tutoring and Academic Success Programs for scholars who fall below HEAF’S minimum academic standards of 80% and above in all core class. Tutors provide assistance to students in the core subject areas and are matched with students based on the coach’s skills in specific subject areas and the student’s needs. Responsibilities: Middle School: Assess and assist students with homework and/or test preparation in at least one of the core subjects: Math, English Language Arts (ELA), Science, and Social Studies - see below for more details about concepts covered in each subject area 6 th Grade Math: ratios, percentages, decimals 7 th Grade Math: solving for X, single variable equations, perimeter, area, circumference 8 th Grade Math: plotting points on a graph, Algebra 1, multiple variable equations 6 th Grade ELA: figurative language, similes, metaphors 7 th Grade ELA: identifying themes in text , drawing inferences, understanding subtext 8 th Grade ELA: comparing and contrasting, analyzing and critically evaluating text, essay writing High School: Assess and assist students in at least one of the core subjects. High School Subject areas that our students have identified needing support in are: Math ( Algebra , Geometry , Trigonometry) Global History US History English Languages ( Spanish, French, Mandarin) Science ( Physics, Biology, Earth Science, Chemistry Evaluate and record student progress after each session Attend and participate in scheduled tutor orientation & training meetings Communicate academic and behavioral progress to program staff Outreach to parents and teachers a minimum of two times per term Create a rich learning environment that aids in instructing students with various learning styles Complete and submit required documentation, including timesheet and session logs Qualifications: Bachelor’s degree preferred - some college required. (Masters students in Education encouraged to apply) Advanced skills in Mathematics, English Language Arts, Science, and/or Social Studies Experience tutoring middle school students Strong work ethic and interpersonal skills Willingness to promote HEAF educational and youth development philosophy Ability to work collaboratively with others Bilingual (Spanish/English) candidates are highly encouraged to apply Prior knowledge of the NYC educational landscape/high school application process is a plus Time Commitment: Academic Tutors are asked to make a minimum of a 90 minutes/week commitment for a minimum of one semester. HEAF’s HEAF@Brooklyn tutoring program operates on Saturdays from 2:30-4:00pm . Support: Orientation will be provided for all tutors at the beginning of each term. Additionally, tutors are given access to a folder of resources that can be used during their sessions. Optional training sessions are offered by our program team. Benefits Build one-on-one relationships with students, while instilling confidence in themselves and their academic abilities Work as part of a collaborative and innovative team Ensure our students have the skills necessary to successfully accomplish their academic goals This position is an unpaid, volunteer position that reports to the HEAF@Brooklyn Site Coordinator and the Associate Director for High Expectations, and is also supported by the Volunteer Engagement Coordinator.
11225.title: HEAF@Brooklyn Academic Tutor

10025.description: Hello! We are D&A. A self-funded non profit based in China aiming to help communities, wherever they are in the world, improve their way of life. We work in three different areas, education, urban farming and recycling and are looking for volunteers who share our excitement for making a positive difference in the world. Having secured funding to expand rapidly we are looking to add 6-8 people to our currently small team, with the vision of growing the number of communities we can help and the scope/scale of our projects. No experience is required, just an enthusiasm for helping people and the desire to come up with new and sustainable ways for communities to grow and gain access to great educational services. All volunteers who can commit a minimum of 6 months with us can gain access to the following benefits: Airfare Subsidies - We understand not everyone who wants to help has the means to get here! As such we have an airfar subsidy scheme enabling us to assist with the cost of coming to China Monthly Allowance - As full-time volunteers you will be provided with a monthly allowance of 3000rmb to cover all living expenses Free Accomodation - All accomodation is provided free of charge to all volunteers Additional Perks! - Dinner nights out with the locals, trips to places of interest in China, on shift meals, ktv signing night, free Chinese language classes and a whole lot more No Charge Promise - Unlike a lot of other volunteer groups and volunteer holidays we promise not to charge you a thing, we just want your enthusiasm and passion for helping people If you would like to find out more, have any questions or talk to us directly please see our website www.dandaschool.com or contact Dec, one of the owners, directly over here or through the website. All successful applicants will undergo a Skype interview with the owners initially, for those applying from the UK we are also able to offer interviews with our small UK based team. Thank you very much for your time, we look forward to hearing from you! Kind Regards, Dec & Any D&A
10025.title: Volunteer in China! We Need Your Passion to Help People! (Airfare subsidy offered)

10025.description: Whether you're great, good or fair at Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM), you can help make an impact on inner-city youth. Here's how: The Parris Foundation S.T.E.M.ulating Minds Weekend Enrichment Program has returned for the Fall 2017 session. The program began after a successful summer pilot in 2012, and our subsequent programs have grown to continue to serve middle school students and high school students . With the growing impact on the community, we need your support to continue to bring STEM to our middle school and high school youth throughout New York City. As we expand to more locations to serve more youth, there is a growing need for volunteers! How we do it: The Parris Foundation curriculum combines innovative and interactive software and teaching techniques with hand-ons interdisciplinary experiments and activities to keep our students engaged with their passion for science and math! About The Parris Foundation: The Parris Foundation is dedicated to promoting educational opportunities and fostering awareness in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) through scholarships and community outreach programs. The Parris Foundation's S.T.E.M.ulating Minds: Weekend Enrichment Programs provide extended learning opportunities to supplement and enhance in-school learning.
10025.title: Fall 2017 - S.T.E.M.ulating Minds Weekend Enrichment Program

10025.description: Top Honors is a non-profit educational organization that provides free math tutoring to NYC 5th, 6th, 7th, and 8th-graders. Tutoring takes place on Saturdays and Wednesday evenings at a school on the Upper West Side. New volunteer orientation and training sessions take place on a rolling basis. To receive an invitation, please submit an application here. Frequently asked questions about the TH volunteer experience can be found on our website. All tutoring sessions take place on the Upper West Side in Manhattan on the following days and times: Session 1: Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 12 p.m. Session 2: Saturdays from 1 p.m. to 3 p.m. Session 3: Wednesdays from 6:30 p.m. to 8 p.m. Volunteers may be professionals, advanced high school, college, or graduate students (community service credit is available). Applicants should be available on Saturdays for two hours starting at 10 a.m. or 1:00 p.m. or on Wednesdays from 6:30 - 8 pm, like math, and enjoy working with students in the middle school age group (10-14 years). No prior experience is necessary. A note on volunteer commitment: Tutors attend 2-3 Saturdays from October and May, which includes holidays and school breaks. To apply, submit an online application at www.tophonors.org/volunteer. Upon receipt, Top Honors will contact the candidate directly with an invitation to attend the next training.
10025.title: Do you love MATH? Volunteer MATH Tutors needed!

10025.description: Travelling to China to volunteer can sometimes be a daunting prospect, and devoting your time is one of the most generous things you can do. At D&A we want our volunteers to know we appreciate this and instead of charging you, as some volunteer companies do, we look to ensure that you aren’t just rewarded through the work you do, but for the amazing people you are! The following positions are available with us, we take each applicant on a case by case basis, experience in these areas isn’t always necessary so don’t hesitate in applying, for us passion beats experience: Education: - English Speaking Teachers - Dance Teachers - Art Teachers - Music Teachers, various instruments Farming: - Urban & Aquatic Farmers Recycling: - Up-cyclers - Jacks of all Trades *Please check our PROJECTS page at www.dandaschool.com/projects for more information about each role We provide all accommodation for free and provide a healthy living allowance for each volunteer who comes to work with us, as well as a long list of random goodies to make your life in China not just enjoyable, but something that will live with you for a lifetime. What is the accommodation like? - Kitchen, shared and fully kitted to enable you to eat how you like when you like - Bedrooms, with soft mattresses. We aim to provide everyone with private rooms, though in some cases shared accommodation - Living Room, comfortable sofa and projector for watching movies, but you’ll normally be out having fun! - Hot water and washing facilities, for those who worry China still hasn’t caught up with the rest of the world! - Electricity and gas provided free of charge, you won’t have to pay a thing Anything else provided? - 4000rmb a month volunteer allowance for use on food, travel or as you see fit - Free use of school bikes and e-bikes to explore the local area and get around - 3 free Chinese language and culture lessons a week - Invitations to family dinners, festivals and cultural events - Tours of the local areas, caves, mountains, lakes and hiking routes - Full \"awake hour\" translation and travel assistance by phone and Skype so you never have to worry about getting lost in translation! - Lots of other small random stuff, meals on the weekends, 2 days off a week, full teacher training, all work materials paid for, the list goes on and on... Who are we looking for? We are looking for bright, talented and imaginative people to come and be apart of our team. You need to be outgoing, fun and ready to create work off your own back, we want to really make a difference and need people who have the same drive and belief to help us achieve this! How do we pay for this? We are a self-funded non-profit, we do this through asking those who can afford our education services (students and partnership schools) to make set donations to us, this enables us to then provide for those who can’t afford it, as well as give funding to our other projects. As such all roles require a minimum of 1-2 days English teaching a week in order to allow us to both fund the projects and enable volunteers to have a great time. If you’d like to learn more about how we fund ourselves in more detail then please CONTACT US with any questions you may have. ​ How long can I stay? Lengths of stay vary depending on what time you would like to commit, most of our positions require a minimum stay of at least 3-6 months due to the type of projects we are looking to carry out and the commitment we have to provide to them. If you are unsure you are able to commit to this length of time then please let us know in your application and for those who want to stay for a while, we are have had people volunteer with us for years.
10025.title: Education, Urban-Farming & Recycling volunteers needed for ambitious project in China!

07310.description: Art House Productions is looking for a professional audio describer for our accessible performance of Not Medea on December 14th at 8pm. The audio describer should come to at least 1 or 2 rehearsals. The audio description equipment for the event is being donated by the NJ Theatre Alliance. Please help us spread the word, Art House is an inclusive environment and so excited to offer audio description again for our blind or low vision patrons.
07310.title: Audio describer needed December 14th

11222.description: The Children’s Tumor Foundation is the leading nonprofit funding source of NF (neurofibromatosis) research in the world. In a few short years, we have grown from a foundation that funds promising science to one that catalyzes the drug discovery process through a series of innovative processes, key partnerships and strategic investments. Do you enjoy helping at an event which raises money for a good cause? We are looking for dedicated volunteers to help to enthusiastically cheer our runners on! Cowbells, thundersticks, wigs, cheer signs and Children's Tumor Foundation t-shirts provided. Shifts: 11:30am-2:30pm on Sun 11/4 12:30-3:30pm on Sun 11/4 1:30-4:30pm on Sun 11/4 Event website: https://join.ctf.org/event/nfe-2018-tcs-new-york-city-marathon/e166085 Volunteer Sign up: https://goo.gl/forms/5wKZImnFWVsDg4jz1
11222.title: NYC Marathon Event Day Volunteers - New York City

11222.description: ISO volunteers for GiGi's Playhouse Satellite station in Greenpoint. GiGi's, a non-profit organization that works with people with-& without Down syndrome. We need helpers who love to enrich and support the lives of others by being there for them, having time to listen, pay special attention, make every single one feel capable and good about themselves; and helping with organizational tasks like setting up the space, helping to follow group instructions, jump, walk, communicate, clean up at the end,..... Our free programs run every Saturday, 10:00-12:00 AM Please contact the following emails: Rpolenz@gigisplayhouse.org bkaufman@gigisplayhouse.org Thank you.
11222.title: Volunteering with children with Down Syndrome in Brooklyn, Greenpoint GiGi's Playhouse Satellite
11222.org: GiGi's Playhouse, Down Syndrome Awareness Centers

11221.description: ACE Integration Head Start is looking for a person to assist in updating their web page , printed materials, E.g. Brochures - Flyers and Parent Handbooks.
11221.title: Writer -Content Manager Web /Brochure

10021.description: When: 11:00-3:00pm on Sunday November 4th Where: Cheering along the TCS NYC Marathon Course. Specific location will be confirmed (likely on Upper East Side) What: You will find a friendly DKMS staff person at each cheering hub. You will be given a t-shirt and DKMS cheering sign to help encourage our team! Why: Team DKMS is raising crucial funds and awareness for the lifesaving mission of DKMS. DKMS is the world's largest bone marrow donation center. We register potential bone marrow donors who could be the match for a blood cancer patient in need of a transplant. We are grateful for our team and want to show them support by cheering them on! RSVP: Please RSVP, if you can attend, to Michele McCaffrey at Michele@dkms.org. This way we can look out for you along the race course!
10021.title: Cheer on Team DKMS in NYC Marathon!

10021.description: The Carter Burden Network is dedicated to supporting the efforts of older people to remain in their homes living independently, safely, and with dignity. Volunteers are an integral component of the Carter Burden Network's 40+ years of success. No matter your age, experience or schedule, CBN can accommodate your needs to ensure that you have a meaningful and effective volunteer experience. Meals-On-Wheels deliver thousands of meals a year to our homebound seniors. The Carter Burden Luncheon Club & Senior Program is looking for eager and passionate volunteers to deliver meals to our Upper East Side senior clients. It's a great opportunity to check up on the senior and converse with them. You're not just delivering a meal, but also a smile! Volunteer hours are from 10:30am to 12:30pm. We need volunteers for the following dates: November 19th, 20th, & 21st
10021.title: Meal Delivery to Homebound Seniors on November 19th, 20th, & 21st

10021.description: Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, widely recognized as one of New York's premier human services providers, is a 124-yeae-old settlement house that provides an extensive array of effective and integrated services which significantly improve the lives of 15,000 people in need each year on the East Side of Manhattan. We are seeking volunteers to serve a lunch meal to older adults at our Senior Center on Friday, 11/23, 11:ooam-12:30pm. Help give joy to older adults in need this holiday season.
10021.title: Thanksgiving Holiday Meal Server

10021.description: Every Saturday morning meals are prepared and delivered for our homebound clients for Saturday as well as Sunday. This Saturday meal delivery also serves as a weekend status check and a friendly visit for clients who receive few, if any, visitors. Meals are delivered on foot to clients living between 69th and 79th Streets, between Fifth Avenue and the East River. Volunteers deliver in pairs or groups and generally visit 4-8 clients. Volunteers should be able to carry 5-10 pounds and walk up several flights of stairs comfortably since some clients live in walk-up buildings. THE CARTER BURDEN CENTER FOR AGING: The Burden Center for the Aging, Inc. promotes the well-being of elderly residents of the Upper East Side of Manhattan through a broad array of direct social services and volunteer programs oriented to individual, family and community needs. We are dedicated to supporting the efforts of older people to remain in their own homes living independently, safely and with dignity.
10021.title: Volunteer Delivering Meals to the Elderly

10021.description: Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, widely recognized as one of New York's premiere human services providers, is a 124-year-old settlement house that provides an extensive array of integrated and effective services which significantly improve the lives of 15,000 in need each year on the East Side of Manhattan. We are seeking volunteers to teach English as a Second Language to beginner level adult students. Volunteers can pick to teach on either Tuesday or Thursday, 9:15am-12:15pm. The class, which runs October 16 - December 4, is a theme-based, integrated skills class that uses a textbook. Training and supervision are provided.
10021.title: English as a Secong Language Teacher

10021.description: Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, widely recognized as one of New York's premier human services providers, is a 124-year-old settlement house that provides an extensive array of effective and integrated services which significantly improve the lives of 15,000 people in need each year on the East Side of Manhattan. We are seeking volunteers with strong computer skills to lead technology workshops for older adult learners. Workshops take place on Mondays, 1:30-3:00, Wednesdays, 1:15-4:30 and Thursdays, 1:30-3:00. Volunteers would commit to teaching workshops on one of these days weekly for the period of October 15 - November 28.
10021.title: Technology Instructor

10021.description: Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, widely recognized as one of New York's premiere human services providers, is a 124-year-old settlement house that provides an extensive array of integrated and effective services which significantly improve the lives of 15,000 people in need each year, on the East Side of Manhattan. We are seeking volunteers with strong computer skills to assist older adults with learning technology in our computer lab. Volunteers will be stationed in the lab to answer students' computer related questions. The lab meets on Fridays, 3:15pm-4:30pm starting September 7.
10021.title: Computer Lab Assistant

10021.description: Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, widely recognized as one of New York's premiere human services providers, is a 124-year-old settlement house that provides an extensive array of integrated and effective services which significantly improve the lives of 15,000 people in need each year, on the East Side of Manhattan. Our Geriatric Care Management Department provides vital social services to homebound older adults, allowing them to age in place within the comfort of their own home. Working under the direction of our Care Managers, the Office Assistant will be responsible for scanning client files, uploading these files to a database and record keeping.
10021.title: Office Assitant - Geriatric Care Management

11743.description: Who doesn't love the warmth and unconditional love from a beautiful four legged furry pet? If you love dogs, and I mean, really love dogs then you can be part of a rewarding experience. Our exclusive Pet Therapy program is currently looking for chaperones. We have committed pet therapy handlers who bring their trained and certified dogs to the hospital to visit our patients. As a chaperone you will be . . . escorting the handler and dog to the patient floors on various units. engaging and interact with our patients & families and wonderful caregivers. providing hand sanitizer to all who pet the dog. greeting patients and introducing the pet handler and pet therapy dog. able to commit to one day a week for a maximum of 2 hours, usually not more than an hour. The presence of a dog in a hospital setting allows the patients to feel more at home, as they do play a small part of the healing process. The immediate gratification you will see on the patients' and staffs' faces when they are interacting with the dog is truly amazing. There are known benefits for pet therapy visits . . . improves mood and overall well-being decreases stress and anxiety lowers blood pressure lets patients reminisce about their own animals If you are interested in volunteering in our program, please contact me for an interview. Alice Messina Coordinator, Patient Experience Pet Therapy Coordinator 631-351-2399 amessina2@northwell.edu
11743.title: Pet Therapy Chaperone

11747.description: Each year Good Shepherd Hospice hosts the Bob Sweeney Children's Holiday Party. This event is for children, ages 5-17, who have experienced the loss of an immediate loved one. Children and their parents attend the morning's therapeutic grief workshops and then engage in holiday themed social activities. Each child is assigned a Volunteer Pal for the day, someone to ensure that each child has fun and gets the attention that they deserve. Pal's participate with their assigned child in the days activities and form a bond that cannot be described. Additional volunteers are needed to assist with the setup and breakdown of the day's activities and to assist with crafts, face painting, games, and entertainment. These very brave children need your help to ensure a fun and therapeutic day! For more information about this event, and to receive an application, please contact: Nadine Moyse, Volunteer Specialist 631-828-7625 or nadine.moyse@chsli.org Barbara Kramer, Volunteer Specialist 631-828-7520 or barbaraa.kramer@chsli.org
11747.title: Children's Bereavement Holiday Party: Volunteers Needed!!

06880.description: CAG is seeking an individual to serve as a Board member who has background in strategic marketing, which ideally includes a blend of marketing planning and execution, with direct experience at an advertising agency or on the client side, with branding, advertising and communications experience. Advocacy experience is also highly regarded. CAG desires assistance to expand its reach, awareness and membership statewide - including further penetration into underserved communities. Also important will be cultivating and maintaining relationships with funders, members, collaborating organizations and legislators as well as the ability to work at a quick pace, flexibly and nimbly. Excellent written and verbal skills are a must. Responsibilities to include the following: Collaborating with the Executive Director and Board leadership to develop and execute a comprehensive marketing and communications plan employing strategies that will broaden programmatic reach and deepen impact, including hands-on experience with all appropriate aspects of social media Managing the ongoing promotion of major programs and developing and executing messaging for new initiatives Identifying and crafting stories that communicate the essence of the organization’s mission and successes Working with the technology-development team to identify a set of meaningful touchpoints with our targets - new member joining, annual pledging - and creating an array of appropriate communications to be automated and sent, in order to stay current and ensure maximum engagement and support from our stakeholders. Working with all CAG committees, specifically including Development and Programming, to assist with execution of their annual plans and to help further corporate engagement efforts Identifying significant media and public policy issues that can be leveraged to support CAG’s work, and creating and implementing plans to exploit them
06880.title: Connecticut Association for the Gifted - BOD Opening in Marketing/Advertising

Can work 4-6 hour shifts Socail Media- (Website, Facebook, Instagram and Twitter) News letters Email Blasts Photography videos Blogging We are non profit organization and we give out scholarships to high students who want to attend college. So if fit the criteria above is you then we want you on our team. All events are not located in ELizabeth, but you must be willing travel and to stay on board for at least 6 months.
